makers.displaymaker: Jan van Doetecum, active 1554–after 1600; born Deventer, Netherlands; died Haarlem, Netherlands
Lucas van Doetecum, ca. 1554–before 1584; born Deventer, Netherlands
Published by Hieronymus Cock, 1507–1570; born and died  Antwerp, Belgium

texts.textentryhtml: Peter Vischer [1751-1823, Lugt 2115]. Junius S. Morgan [1867-1932]; bequeathed to Princeton University Art Museum, 1932.

Brueghel’s biographer stated that during the artist’s Alpine journey to Italy he swallowed up the mountains—and then spat them out onto his paintings following his return to Antwerp. The trip inspired Bruegel to design a set of twelve large landscape etchings based on his drawings of actual sites. Throughout these panoramic settings, of which this example is the grandest, Bruegel embedded numerous tiny figures. While many are busy with daily tasks, such as tilling fields or tending animals, there are also moments of leisure: two fishermen sit on the riverbank and a solitary man rests under a tree, almost directly above the artist’s signature. Labor clearly dominates rustic life, as is implied by the title and underscored by the presence of two workers in the lower right corner.
